awd_titl_txt: Understanding particle acceleration in collisionless shocks using kinetic simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Collisionless shocks occur in tenuous plasmas where the mean free path for collisions mediated by electrostatic interaction is large, as found in supernova remnants, clusters of galaxies, relativistic jets, and pulsar winds.  The conditions under which this occurs, and the efficiency of accelerating charged particles, are not well understood.  This project will carry out advanced numerical simulations and use them to construct a self-consistent theory of shock acceleration.  It will resolve the complex microphysics of plasma instabilities, particle scattering, and magnetic field generation and amplification, and calibrate the theory for its application to astrophysical objects.  The results will help to interpret new studies of high-energy astrophysical and cosmological sources, including the next generation of laboratory experiments, and the physical insights will even apply to shocks in our solar system.  The work will train graduate and undergraduate students in numerical modeling and the visualization of multiscale systems, mentor a postdoc, and support open source simulation software and its analysis tools.

Collisionless shocks span different speeds and strengths of magnetic field, and accelerate both nonthermal electrons which energize synchrotron emission, and the protons commonly found in cosmic rays.  The main process is thought to be diffusive shock acceleration, in which particles scatter on magnetic fluctuations, but the conditions for this Fermi mechanism and its efficiency are not understood from first principles.  This project will carry out large-scale multidimensional particle-in-cell (PIC) and hybrid simulations of astrophysical collisionless shocks to consider: 1) what is the relative efficiency of acceleration as a function of shock speed, Mach number, and magnetic inclination? 2) what waves mediate electron acceleration in quasi-parallel and quasi-perpendicular shocks? 3) what is the ratio of electron to ion temperature downstream, and what is the physics of energy transfer? 4) what is the nonlinear structure of the shock when ion acceleration is efficient?  With microphysical parameterizations measured with PIC simulations, new software will combine a magneto-hydrodynamic description of the background plasma with kinetic particles to represent cosmic rays and their back-reaction on the flow.  This will enable modeling of macroscopic astrophysical objects such as supernova remnants or galactic outflows, including the effects of cosmic rays and their acceleration.  These kinetic simulations address how nonlinear shock acceleration works and will constrain the parameters of the flow when it is efficient.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Collisionless shock waves are of primary importance in astrophysical sources of high energy radiation and in the heliosphere. They occur, for example, when cosmic explosions, such as supernovae, launch supersonically moving ejecta through the rarefied gas of the interstellar medium. The density there is so low that interparticle collisions are very rare, so that the shocked ionized gas (or plasma) is effectively “collisionless”. The shock waves in such collisionless plasma are mediated by plasma instabilities and are known to accelerate a minority of particles to speeds close to the speed of light. These particles, known as cosmic rays, gain energy via repeated crossings of the shock, in the process known as Fermi acceleration. The research in this grant was concerned with determining the physics of such particle acceleration and what determines the fraction of particles that are accelerated by the shock. The findings in this proposal helped to clarify the internal structure of collisionless shocks and the physics that drives the shock transition. The research was performed by means of particle-in-cell simulations that model the motion of charged particles in the plasma in self-consistent electromagnetic fields. Such simulations are the most fundamental and ab-initio method for modeling the plasma dynamics. The project resulted in the largest library of nonrelativistic collisionless shock simulations in different conditions of magnetic field strength and flow velocity. A new regime of electron acceleration in shocks with strongly inclined magnetic field lines was discovered as a result of this numerical shock survey. 

The study of small-scale physics of the shock transition resulted in the determination of the fraction of ion energy transferred to electrons in the form of heat at the shock. This energy transfer is difficult to predict without the kinetic modeling. The PI and students quantified this heating through both the supercomputer simulations and an analytical model. The structure of the shock was also found to determine the fraction of particles injected into the acceleration process, and specific magnetic filamentary structures were identified as being responsible for the initial reflection of particles upon shock crossing. On larger scales, the research under this grant resulted in the development of simulations with a novel method that can couple kinetic particle simulations with a fluid description for the background particles. These simulations allowed the first multi-scale shock simulations with self-consistent particle injection and demonstrated the mechanisms for large scale feedback that regulate particle injection in realistic conditions. These findings provide a particle injection prescription that can be used in fluid simulations for including the effects of shock acceleration. 

The results of this research are being used for interpreting the observations of supernova remnants, and solar wind shocks in the heliosphere. In particular, the long term simulations demonstrated the emergence of large amplitude magnetic turbulence driven by cosmic rays in front of the shocks. These magnetic structures can trap and affect the spectrum of electrons, which may explain the observed unusual slope of the electron energy spectrum of young supernova remnants. 

The grant supported 3 postdoctoral fellows and 3 graduate students, in addition to summer undergraduate students. The scientific outcomes included 16 peer-reviewed papers and numerous presentations at conferences and invited talks. Broader impacts included outreach events and public presentations about high energy and cosmic ray astrophysics. The results of this research have also been applied in laboratory settings to study shock creation and particle acceleration using ultra-intense laser-plasma experiments at Rochester’s Omega laser and at the National Ignition Facility.
